Short English Translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, after assembling in the holy land of Kurukshetra and desiring to fight, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?
Sanjaya said: On observing the Pandava army arranged in military formation, King Duryodhana approached his teacher Dronacharya and spoke these words.
Behold, O teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada, your wise disciple.
Here in this army are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhima and Arjuna: Yuyudhana, Virata, and Drupada, the maharatha.
There are also great, heroic, powerful fighters like Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the king of Kashi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Shaibya, the best of men.
The strong Yudhamanyu and the brave Uttamauja, the son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi—all great chariot-warriors.
O best of Brahmins, hear also about the principal generals on our side, who are especially qualified to lead. These I now recount unto you.
There are personalities like yourself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, Ashwatthama, Vikarna, and Bhurishrava, who are ever victorious in battle.
And many other heroes who are determined to give up their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled in battle.
Our strength is immeasurable, and we are perfectly protected by Grandfather Bhishma, whereas the strength of the Pandavas, carefully protected by Bhima, is limited.
Therefore, all of you stationed in your respective positions on all sides, protect Grandfather Bhishma alone.
Then Bhishma, the great valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, blew his conch very loudly like the roar of a lion, giving joy to Duryodhana.
After that, conches, kettledrums, tabors, trumpets, and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.
On the other side, both Krishna and Arjuna, stationed on a grand chariot drawn by white horses, sounded their transcendental conches.
Krishna blew His conch named Panchajanya; Arjuna blew his, the Devadatta; and Bhima, the voracious eater and performer of heroic tasks, blew the Paundra conch.
King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya conch; Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and Manipushpaka conches.
The great archer King of Kashi, the great fighter Shikhandi, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and the invincible Satyaki blew their conches.
Drupada, the sons of Draupadi, and the mighty-armed son of Subhadra also blew their conches, O King.
The sound resounding through the sky and the earth shattered the hearts of the sons of Dhritarashtra.
At that time, Arjuna, the son of Pandu, seated in the chariot bearing the banner of Hanuman, took up his bow and prepared to speak to Krishna.
Arjuna said: O Krishna, please place my chariot between the two armies.
So that I may see those assembled here, eager to fight, with whom I must engage in this great battle.
Let me look at those who have come here desiring to please the evil-minded Duryodhana.
Sanjaya said: Thus requested by Arjuna, Krishna placed the chariot between the two armies.
In front of Bhishma, Drona, and all the other kings, Krishna said: Behold, O Arjuna, all the Kurus assembled here.
Then Arjuna saw in both armies fathers, grandfathers, teachers, uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, and well-wishers.
Seeing all these relatives present, Arjuna, overwhelmed with compassion and despair, spoke the following.
Arjuna said: Seeing my own kinsmen gathered here, ready to fight, my limbs fail, my mouth dries up.
My body trembles, my hair stands on end, my bow slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over.
I am unable to stand here any longer. My mind is reeling, and I see only omens of misfortune, O Krishna!
I do not see any good in killing my kinsmen in battle, O Krishna. I desire no victory, kingdom, or pleasures.
What is the use of the kingdom, pleasures, or life itself if those for whom we desire them are present here to die in battle?
Teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives...
...for whose sake we desire gain, are here in battle, ready to give up their lives and wealth.
I do not wish to kill them, even if I am killed, not even for the sovereignty of the three worlds, what to speak of the earth!
Sin will overcome us if we kill such aggressors. Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra and our relatives.
How can we be happy by killing our own kinsmen, O Madhava?
Though they are driven by greed and see no wrong in destroying families, why should we, who see the sin, engage in this crime?
With the destruction of the family, the eternal family tradition is lost, and the rest of the family becomes irreligious.
When irreligion prevails, the women of the family become corrupt, and from such corruption, unwanted progeny are born.
By the rise of unwanted progeny, family traditions and duties are destroyed, and eternal dharma perishes.
Such a breach leads those who destroy family traditions to dwell perpetually in hell.
O Krishna, we have heard that those who destroy family traditions dwell always in hell.
Alas, we are engaged in committing a great sin, driven by greed, ready to kill our own kin.
It would be better if the sons of Dhritarashtra, armed, killed me unarmed and unresisting.
Sanjaya said: Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and sat down in his chariot, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow.
Arjuna’s will collapses completely, and he remains despondent in the middle of the battlefield.
Sanjaya said: Seeing Arjuna full of compassion and despair, with tearful eyes, Krishna spoke the following words.
Krishna said: From where has this dejection come upon you in this hour of crisis? It is not fitting for an Aryan.
O Arjuna, give up this petty weakness of heart. Rise, O scorcher of enemies!
Arjuna said: How can I fight against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of worship, O Krishna?
It is better to live by begging than to kill great souls.
We do not know which is better—conquering or being conquered.
I am confused about my duty. I ask You to tell me clearly what is best. I am Your disciple, surrendered to You.
I see no solution to this sorrow that is drying up my senses.
Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus, Arjuna remained silent and sat with a heavy heart.
Krishna, with a gentle smile, began to speak profound words to the despondent Arjuna.
You grieve for those who should not be grieved for, yet speak words of wisdom. The wise do not mourn the living or the dead.
Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings—nor will any of us cease to exist in the future.
Just as childhood, youth, and old age happen to the body, so does the passing to another body. The wise are not deluded by this.
Pleasure and pain, heat and cold arise from sense perception. They come and go—endure them, O Arjuna.
That person who remains undisturbed in pleasure and pain is fit for immortality.
The unreal has no existence; the real never ceases to be. Truth is discerned by seers.
That by which all is pervaded is indestructible. No one can destroy the imperishable soul.
Bodies are perishable; the indwelling Self is eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable.
He who thinks the soul kills or is killed is ignorant. The soul neither kills nor is killed.
The soul is never born, never dies, nor ceases to exist. It is unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient.
One who knows this eternal soul as indestructible cannot kill nor cause killing.
As a person discards worn-out clothes, so the soul discards old bodies and takes new ones.
Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it.
This soul is unbreakable, incombustible, insoluble, and constant.
It is said to be invisible, inconceivable, and immutable. Knowing this, you should not grieve.
Even if you think the soul is born and dies, still you should not grieve.
Death is certain for the born and birth for the dead. So you should not lament over the inevitable.
All beings are unmanifest before birth, manifest between birth and death, and unmanifest again. Why lament?
Some see the soul as amazing, others speak of it as amazing, and others even after hearing do not understand it.
The soul residing in the body can never be slain. Therefore, you should not grieve for any creature.
Considering your dharma as a warrior, you should not waver. For a warrior, nothing is better than a righteous battle.
Fortunate are the warriors who gain such an opportunity for righteous war, opening the gates of heaven.
But if you do not engage in this righteous war, then abandoning your dharma and honor, you shall incur sin.
People will speak of your infamy forever. For a man of honor, dishonor is worse than death.
Great generals will think you fled the battlefield out of fear. You will lose your reputation.
Your enemies will mock your ability. What can be more painful than that?
If you are killed, you will attain heaven; if you win, you enjoy the earth. Therefore, rise and fight.
Treat pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat alike, and engage in battle. Then you will not incur sin.
This knowledge has been taught to you from the Sankhya perspective. Now hear it from the standpoint of Karma Yoga.
In this path, no effort is ever wasted, and there is no failure. Even a little progress protects from great fear.
Those with resolute intellect have single-pointed focus. The minds of the irresolute are many-branched.
The unwise delight in the flowery words of the Vedas, saying there is nothing else.
Attached to pleasure and power, their minds are not led to true concentration.
Those whose minds are attracted to enjoyment and power cannot possess the steady intellect of the meditative.
The Vedas deal with the three gunas. Rise above them, O Arjuna. Be established in the Self, beyond gain and protection.
All the purposes of a well can be served by a vast lake. Similarly, one who knows the Absolute transcends Vedic ritual.
You have the right to work, but not to the fruits. Never be attached to results.
Perform your duty with equanimity, abandoning attachment. Success and failure are equal. This is Yoga.
Action is far inferior to Buddhi Yoga (wisdom in action). Take refuge in wisdom.
One who is devoted to Buddhi Yoga casts off both good and bad actions.
The wise, united with Buddhi Yoga, abandon the fruits of action and attain eternal peace.
When your intellect crosses beyond delusion, you shall be indifferent to heard and unheard teachings.
When your intellect, confused by the Vedas, becomes steady in Self-realization, then you shall attain Yoga.
Arjuna asks: What is the description of a self-realized person? How does such a person speak, sit, walk?
Krishna replies: When one gives up desires, satisfied in the Self alone, one is called steadfast in wisdom.
One who is not disturbed by pain or pleasure and is free from attachment, fear, and anger is truly wise.
One who is unattached in all situations and neither rejoices nor hates when good or bad occurs is firmly established in wisdom.
Like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs, a wise person withdraws senses from sense objects.
The objects may cease for the abstainer, but taste remains. Even that disappears upon Self-realization.
The turbulent senses forcibly carry away even the mind of a wise person striving for perfection.
Restraining all senses, the wise should sit focused on Me. One whose senses are under control is steadfast.
While contemplating objects, attachment arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.
From anger comes delusion; from delusion, memory loss; from memory loss, intellect is destroyed; from loss of intellect, ruin follows.
But one who moves among objects with senses under control, free from attachment and aversion, attains peace.
In that peace, all sorrows are destroyed. The intellect of the peaceful soon becomes steady.
Without steady intellect, there is no contemplation; without contemplation, no peace; and without peace, how can there be happiness?
When the mind follows the wandering senses, it carries away the intellect like the wind carries a boat on water.
Therefore, O mighty-armed, one whose senses are completely restrained has steady wisdom.
What is night to others is day to the disciplined; what is day to others is night to the sage.
Like an ocean unmoved by rivers, one who is unmoved by desires attains peace.
One who abandons desires and ego, and acts without possessiveness, attains peace.
This is the Brahmic state. Established in it, one is never deluded and attains oneness with Brahman at death.
Arjuna asked: If knowledge is superior to action, why do You ask me to engage in this terrible action, O Krishna?
My mind is confused about what is right. Tell me definitively what is best.
Krishna said: There are two paths: Jnana Yoga (path of knowledge) and Karma Yoga (path of action).
One does not attain freedom from action by merely avoiding work, nor by renunciation alone.
No one can remain inactive even for a moment. Nature forces everyone to act.
One who externally restrains actions but internally dwells on objects is a hypocrite.
But one who controls the senses and performs actions without attachment excels.
Do your prescribed duty. Action is better than inaction. Even survival depends on action.
Action must be done as sacrifice. Otherwise, it binds.
In the beginning, Prajapati created beings along with sacrifice, saying: prosper through this.
Nourish the gods through sacrifice, and they will nourish you in return.
Those who enjoy offerings without giving back are thieves.
The righteous eat what remains after sacrifice; others eat only sin.
From food comes beings; from rain comes food; from sacrifice comes rain.
Karma arises from the Vedas, and the Vedas arise from the imperishable Brahman.
He who does not follow this wheel of creation lives in sin and is a parasite.
But one who rejoices in the Self, is content in the Self, and is fulfilled in the Self—has no duty.
Such a person has no dependence on anyone and is not bound by action or inaction.
Therefore, perform your duty without attachment, for by detached action one attains the Supreme.
Janaka and others attained perfection by action. Perform duty for the sake of the world.
Whatever a great person does, others follow. Whatever standard they set, the world adopts.
I have nothing to achieve in all three worlds, yet I engage in action.
If I did not act, O Partha, the worlds would perish; I would be the cause of chaos.
If I ceased to perform duties, all beings would follow my path and be ruined.
The ignorant act with attachment; the wise act without attachment, to guide the world.
The wise should not disturb the beliefs of the ignorant but inspire them through example.
All actions are performed by the gunas; the deluded think “I am the doer.”
The wise understand this and do not attach themselves to actions.
Those deluded by gunas become attached to actions. The wise should not unsettle them.
Surrender all actions to Me, with knowledge and detachment, and engage in battle.
Those who follow My teaching with faith and without envy are freed from bondage.
But those who scorn this teaching and are deluded—they are lost in ignorance.
Even the wise act according to their nature. What will restraint accomplish?
Attraction and aversion to sense objects arise from nature. Do not be controlled by them.
Better one’s own duty, though imperfect, than the duty of another, well-performed.
Arjuna asks: What impels a person to sin, even unwillingly, as if by force?
Krishna says: It is desire and anger, born of rajas, which devour and compel action.
Just as fire is obscured by smoke, mirror by dust, fetus by womb—knowledge is obscured by desire.
Desire is the constant enemy of the wise, ever enveloping wisdom.
Desire resides in senses, mind, and intellect—it clouds the soul.
Control the senses first, then destroy this enemy of wisdom.
The senses are superior to the body, the mind to the senses, the intellect to the mind, and the Self is above the intellect.
Thus, knowing the Self to be higher, control the self with the Self and destroy desire.
I taught this eternal Yoga to Vivasvan (sun-god), who taught it to Manu, who passed it to Ikshvaku.
This wisdom was passed down through royal sages. Over time, it was lost.
Today I teach you this ancient wisdom, because you are My devotee and friend.
Arjuna asks: You were born recently; how did You teach this long ago?
Krishna replies: I have had many births, and so have you. I remember them all; you do not.
Though unborn and eternal, I manifest by My own maya to protect the good and destroy evil.
Whenever dharma declines and adharma rises, I manifest Myself.
To protect the righteous, destroy the wicked, and establish dharma, I appear in every age.
One who knows the truth of My birth and actions is not reborn. They attain Me.
Freed from desire and fear, many have taken refuge in Me and been purified by knowledge.
As they approach Me, I reciprocate. All paths lead to Me.
People worship the gods for quick results, but such fruit is limited.
I created the fourfold varna system based on guna and karma, yet I am not the doer.
Actions do not bind Me, as I have no desire for their fruits.
Knowing this, ancient seekers acted. Therefore, you should also act.
What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused.
One must understand action, forbidden action, and inaction.

Short English Translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is wise.
The wise whose actions are free from desire and whose works are burnt by knowledge are called sages.
Renouncing attachment, content with what comes, not dependent—one acts without bondage.
One who performs action without desire, controlling the mind, gains peace through renunciation.
Content with what comes, free of envy, stable in success and failure, he is not bound by action.
All his actions, being offered in sacrifice, are dissolved.
The act of offering, the oblation, and the fire are all Brahman. One who sees this attains Brahman.
Some offer sacrifices to gods; others offer as Brahman itself.
Some offer the senses into restraint; others offer sound into hearing.
Others offer all sense functions into the fire of self-control.
Some offer wealth, austerity, or study. Others practice breath regulation as sacrifice.
Breath is offered into breath—through control of inhalation and exhalation.
All these understand sacrifice and are purified by it.
Those who partake of the nectar of sacrifice reach the eternal.
Sacrifices are various and rooted in action. Knowing this, one is liberated.
Knowledge-sacrifice is superior to material sacrifice. All actions culminate in knowledge.
Learn from the wise by humility, inquiry, and service—they will teach you the Truth.
Once you realize this, you will not fall into delusion again. You will see all beings in the Self.
Even the worst sinner can cross the ocean of sin by the boat of knowledge.
Just as fire burns fuel, knowledge burns all karma.
Nothing purifies like knowledge. One who is perfected by Yoga finds it in time.
A faithful, devoted, and controlling aspirant gains knowledge.
Ignorant, faithless, and doubting souls are ruined—no peace, no joy, no world.
Actions are renounced by those with doubt destroyed by knowledge, established in the Self.
Therefore, cut through doubt with the sword of knowledge. Rise, O Bharata, and act!
Arjuna asks: Which is better—renunciation of action or acting with detachment?
Krishna replies: Both lead to liberation, but Karma Yoga is superior.
One who neither hates nor desires is truly a renunciant, free from dualities and bondage.
The ignorant see Sankhya and Karma Yoga as different; the wise see them as one.
What one gains through Sankhya, the other attains through Karma Yoga.
Renunciation is hard without discipline. The Karma Yogi quickly reaches Brahman.
A purified soul, self-controlled and detached, performs action yet is untouched by it.
The wise say, “I do nothing at all,” though engaged in seeing, hearing, touching, etc.
Offering sense actions to nature, the soul remains unattached.
One who offers actions to Brahman and is detached is untainted by sin—like a lotus in water.
Yogis act with body, mind, intellect, and senses—for self-purification, not gain.
The detached one attains peace; the attached one, bound by craving, gets results.
The embodied being, detached from actions, lives happily in the city of nine gates.
The Self does not create action, agency, or results; nature does all this.
The Lord does not accept virtue or sin. Knowledge is veiled by ignorance.
For those whose ignorance is destroyed, knowledge illuminates the Self.
Fixed on the Self, devoted, disciplined, they attain liberation from bondage.
A sage sees the same in a learned priest, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and a dog-eater.
Even here, the steady-minded conquer rebirth, being Brahman-abiding and faultless.
Unmoved by pleasure or pain, knowing the Self—such a one abides in Brahman.
Not rejoicing in the pleasant nor sorrowing over the unpleasant—such one is wise.
Sense pleasures lead to pain and have a beginning and end; the wise do not delight in them.
One who can resist desire and anger until death is truly happy.
Inner joy, peace, and light—such a one attains Brahman.
Sages purified by knowledge and engaged in service attain the eternal.
Those free from desire and anger, controlled in thought, realize Brahman.
Shutting out sense objects, controlling breath and mind, the yogi seeks liberation.
Free of fear and anger, steady in the vow of liberation, the sage is forever free.
Knowing Me as the enjoyer of all sacrifice and austerity, the Supreme Lord of all worlds—such a person attains peace.
One who performs duty without attachment to results is a true renunciant and yogi, not one who merely gives up fire or action.
Renunciation is selfless action, not abandonment. One free of desire is a true sannyasi.
For the beginner, action is the means; for the perfected, stillness is the means.
When one is detached from all sense objects and actions, they are said to be elevated.
Elevate yourself through the Self, never degrade. You are your own friend and enemy.
One who has conquered the mind is a friend; one who fails, the mind acts as an enemy.
A tranquil person is at peace in heat and cold, pleasure and pain, honor and dishonor.
The one content with knowledge and Self-realization, detached and balanced, is the perfected yogi.
A yogi who treats friends, enemies, and neutrals alike is superior.
A yogi should always practice solitude, self-control, and detachment.
In a clean place, set up a firm seat neither too high nor low.
Sitting there, restraining the mind and senses, the yogi should concentrate on the Self.
Keeping body, neck, and head steady, gaze at the tip of the nose—without distraction.
With peaceful mind and fearless heart, celibate, focused on Me—such a yogi attains Me.
Constantly disciplining the mind, the yogi attains peace and liberation.
Yoga is not for one who eats too much or too little, or sleeps too much or too little.
For one balanced in eating, sleeping, working, and recreation, yoga becomes the destroyer of sorrow.
When mind is restrained and fixed on the Self, one is said to be absorbed in Yoga.
As a steady flame in a windless place, so is the yogi’s mind fixed in meditation.
When the mind ceases from mental activities and rests in the Self, the yogi attains fulfillment.
That which is grasped by intelligence and beyond the senses is realized by the tranquil yogi.
Having attained that, one does not consider any gain higher. Not shaken by sorrow.
Know this state as yoga: severing contact with sorrow. Practice with firm resolve.
Renounce all desires born of imagination and restrain the senses gradually.
Through steady intellect and detachment, the Self should be established firmly.
When the mind wanders, bring it back under the control of the Self.
A yogi with a subdued mind attains peace, rooted in Me, free from sin.
The yogi constantly unites with Me and experiences supreme bliss.
He sees the Self in all beings and all beings in the Self.
One who sees Me everywhere and everything in Me is never lost to Me.
He who is established in this unity, worships Me in all beings, and dwells in Me.
The best yogi sees others' pain and joy as their own.
Arjuna asks: The yoga you describe seems hard—how can a restless mind attain it?
The mind is restless, turbulent, strong, and stubborn—difficult to control.
Krishna says: With practice and detachment, the mind can be controlled.
Without self-control, Yoga is difficult; with striving, it is attainable.
Arjuna asks: What happens to the yogi who fails—who doesn’t reach perfection?
Does he perish like a cloud torn apart? Lost from both paths?
Krishna, please resolve this doubt completely. None but You can do it.
Krishna replies: A fallen yogi is never destroyed. One who does good is never overcome by evil.
The fallen yogi is born into a family of righteousness or wisdom.
Or into a family of enlightened yogis—rare indeed is such a birth.
There he regains the intellect of previous births and strives for perfection.
Drawn by previous practice, he moves forward, even against his will.
Through many births, purified yogis attain the supreme goal.
The yogi is greater than the ascetic, the scholar, and the ritualist. Be a yogi.
Of all yogis, the one who surrenders to Me with love is highest.
Fix your mind on Me. With practice and devotion, you will know Me fully.
I will now explain knowledge and realization, knowing which nothing more remains to be known.
Among thousands, one strives for perfection; of those, few truly know Me.
My lower nature is eightfold: earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and ego.
My higher nature is the life-principle that sustains the world.
All beings are born from these two natures. I am the source and end of the universe.
There is nothing higher than Me. All things are strung on Me like pearls on a thread.
I am the taste in water, the light in the sun and moon, and the syllable Om in the Vedas.
I am the fragrance of earth, the heat in fire, and the life in all beings.
I am the seed of all beings, the intelligence of the intelligent, and the power of the powerful.
I am the strength free from passion and desire.
All states—sattva, rajas, tamas—arise from Me. But I am not in them; they are in Me.
Deluded by these gunas, people do not know Me, the imperishable beyond nature.
This Maya of Mine is divine and hard to overcome. Those who surrender to Me cross it.
The deluded, evil, foolish, and those with demonic nature do not surrender to Me.
Four types of virtuous ones worship Me: the distressed, the seeker of knowledge, the wealth-seeker, and the wise.
Of these, the wise one, ever steadfast, devoted to the One, is dearest to Me.
All are noble, but the wise is like My own Self. Such a devotee reaches Me.
After many births, the wise realize Me as all. Such a great soul is rare.
Those whose knowledge is stolen by desire worship other deities.
Whatever form a devotee worships, I make that faith steady.
Endowed with faith, he gets his desired object. But it is Me who fulfills all.
But the fruit of limited worship is temporary. Those who worship gods go to them; My devotees come to Me.
The ignorant think I am unmanifest and take a form. They do not know My higher, immutable nature.
I am not revealed to all, veiled by My Maya. The deluded do not know Me as unborn and eternal.
I know the past, present, and future of all beings, but no one knows Me.
All beings are born in delusion, overcome by desire and hatred.
Those whose sins are destroyed, who are engaged in vows, are freed from delusion and worship Me.
Those who strive for liberation take refuge in Me, knowing Brahman, karma, and all action.
Arjuna asks: What is Brahman, karma, the Self, the divine, and sacrifice?
Who resides in the body? How do the yogis reach You at death?
Krishna: Brahman is the supreme imperishable; adhyatma is the inner self; karma is action producing embodiment.
Adhibhuta is perishable matter; adhidaiva is the cosmic soul; adhiyajna is Me, residing in all beings.
One who remembers Me at death attains My being.
As one remembers at death, so one becomes.
Always remember Me and fight. With mind and intellect surrendered, you will reach Me.
With sustained practice, one attains Me.
One who meditates on the Supreme Person, omniscient and timeless, attains Him.
At the time of death, with a steady mind and devotion, the yogi reaches that supreme.
The imperishable goal of the Vedas, realized by renunciants through celibacy and self-control.
At the time of death, closing senses, placing prana in the head, the yogi unites with Brahman.
Chanting Om and departing the body with devotion to Me—he attains the Supreme.
Constant remembrance and devotion lead one easily to Me.
Those who attain Me do not return to this world of suffering.
All worlds up to Brahma’s are subject to return—but not so for My devotees.
One day of Brahma equals a thousand yugas, and so does one night.
All beings manifest at dawn and dissolve at dusk of Brahma’s day.
Again and again this multitude is born, helplessly bound to the cycle.
Beyond this is an eternal, unmanifest realm, never destroyed.
That eternal, unmanifest, is called the supreme goal; reaching it, none return.
The Supreme is attained through exclusive devotion.
I will tell you the times at which yogis depart and do not return, and those when they return.
Fire, light, daytime, the bright fortnight, and the six months of the northward sun—these lead to Brahman.
Smoke, night, the dark fortnight, and the southern course—these lead to rebirth.
These two paths—bright and dark—are eternal. One leads to no return, the other to return.
The yogi who knows both paths is never deluded.
Knowing this, the yogi surpasses all Vedic rites and attains the supreme goal.
Krishna: I shall now declare to you the most secret wisdom, by knowing which you will be liberated.
This knowledge is the king of sciences, righteous, easy to practice, and imperishable.
Those without faith in this truth do not attain Me and return to samsara.
I pervade all beings. All exist in Me, but I am not in them.
Beings do not dwell in Me truly—behold My divine mystery.
As wind moves in space, so beings exist in Me.
At the end of a cycle, all beings merge into My nature. I recreate them again.
I send them forth again due to nature’s force—helplessly bound to karma.
These actions do not bind Me—I remain unattached and neutral.
Nature works under My supervision to manifest the world.
Fools mock Me when I appear in human form, unaware of My supreme nature.
Deluded minds cling to demonic nature, futile actions, and false knowledge.
But the great souls take refuge in Me, knowing Me as eternal and imperishable.
Constantly chanting, resolved in vows, they worship Me with unwavering faith.
Others worship Me through knowledge, seeing Me in unity, diversity, and all forms.

I give heat, send rain, hold back and release it. I am immortality and death, being and non-being.
The ritualists go to heaven, enjoy celestial pleasures, and return after merit is exhausted.
After their pleasure, they fall back to earth. The fruit of limited devotion is impermanent.
But those who worship Me with exclusive devotion, I preserve what they have and provide what they lack.
